Catalytic oxidation of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids is regarded as an important technology for sustainable traditional oxidation processes in industry. Despite decades of research and several breakthroughs in catalyst design, the precise reaction mechanism underlying the formation of specific carboxylic acids remains elusive. In this review, the oxidation of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids over metallic catalysts is systematically summarized with a focus on surface reaction mechanisms and catalyst design strategies. Essentially, the activation of C-H bond and the competitive adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates serve as critical issues in determining the reaction mechanism. Insights into the reaction mechanism, the structure-performance relationships of oxophilic metal-based catalysts in various low-carbon polyol oxidation reactions lay the groundwork for rational catalyst design and manufacturing: (I) well-dispersed acidic sites can enhance the electronic density of oxophilic metals, thereby improving the H abstraction efficiency, while an adequate number of weak basic sites on the surface is beneficial for the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates; (II) the downshifted d-band center of oxophilic metal sites results in greater catalytic efficiency for C-H bond activation. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of oxidation mechanisms and guide the rational design of efficient catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Low-carbon polyols Primary carboxylic acids Oxidation Mechanism Oxophilic metal-based catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The advocacy for global carbon neutrality and green chemistry underscores the necessity of utilizing renewable resources and producing low-carbon chemicals [1–3]. The selective oxidation of biomass derived low-carbon polyols (C2-C6) to primary carboxylic acids constitutes a fundamental process within the domains of green chemistry and sustainable chemical transformation [4]. Primary carboxylic acids with low carbon numbers (including glycolic acid (GA), lactic acid (LA), glyceric acid (GLYA), 2-hydroxybutyric acid, and 6-hydroxyhexanoic acid (HA)) have garnered significant attention due to their extensive applications in the food industry and as chemical feedstocks. Generally, monometallic noble metal catalysts (such as Pt, Pd, and Au) and noble metal-based bimetallic catalysts (including AuPt and AuPd) have been employed for these oxidation reactions (Scheme 1 ) [5–7]. However, the oxidation activity and selectivity of these existing catalysts remain unsatisfactory, mainly due to the highly functionalized nature of multiple hydroxyl groups in the reactants, which can lead to interference from other C-H and O-H groups during position-specific hydroxyl oxidation [8,9]. Consequently, the design and development of efficient and highly selective catalysts for the oxidation of low-carbon polyols to produce carboxylic acid products will be pivotal for future advancements in this field. The rational design of catalysts is heavily reliant on a profound understanding of the reaction mechanism [10]. One major challenge is that, while C-H activation is recognized as the rate-determining step (RDS) in the catalytic oxidation of alcohols, the activation of the C-H bond at specific positions on the active site occurs multiple times throughout the reaction [11,12]. This complexity complicates the analysis of the key step in the reaction. By concentrating on the C-H activation as the pivotal step, it becomes essential to explore how factors such as the active metal, metal dispersion, support, and auxiliary components enhance the H abstraction ability from the C-H bond over the active site. On the other hand, during the oxidation reaction, the competitive adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates, which can induce undesired parallel reactions and deep oxidation reactions such as C-C bond cleavage, further complicates the formulation of the reaction mechanism [13,14]. Therefore, it is of great importance to establish reasonable requirements for the electronic and geometric structures of the catalyst, guided by a detailed investigation of the reaction mechanisms for various low-carbon polyols, to achieve the activation of specific chemical bonds and thereby enhance catalytic performance in a targeted manner. This work overviews the catalytic oxidation of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids over supported catalysts from the perspective of the reaction mechanism. There are two different mechanisms in the oxidation process: one mechanism dominated by tautomeric equilibrium between C=O and C-O groups and another mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation. A detailed analysis of oxophilic metal sites with varying electronic affinities explains the underlying reasons for different oxidation mechanisms. In particular, H abstraction ability and the competitive adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates underscore the critical role of the high electron-cloud density at oxophilic metal sites and the suitable electronic configuration near active sites. Based on the suitability of various low-carbon polyols with specific catalysts, we summarize the reported improvements in their conversion by optimizing the composition of the oxophilic active components, adjusting the surface concentration of acid/base sites on the support, and tailoring the structures of the oxophilic metal-support interface. In addition, we propose a prospective trajectory for advancing low-carbon polyol oxidation efficiency, addressing the limitations of current catalyst designs and ultimately facilitating the large-scale production of primary carboxylic acids through mechanism-guided rational design. 2 Mechanism of low-carbon polyol oxidation to primary carboxylic acid on oxophilic metal-based catalysts The type of reaction mechanism may be closely related to the properties of catalysts used in the oxidation process. For example, reaction kinetics have revealed that Cu-based catalysts, such as CuFeOX and Cu@Cu-N-C5, demonstrated impressive activity (TOF: 1410 h-1 and 111.7 h-1), surpassing the highly active noble metal catalyst in traditional applications, such as Pd/HAP and Ag (TOF: 53 h-1 and 25.2 h-1) [15,16]. Noble metal active centers like Pd and Ag do not exhibit superior catalytic performance. Instead, non-noble metal active centers like Cu offer greater catalytic efficiency for the dehydrogenation of the C-H bond and fewer by-products [14,17]. This suggests that the oxidation of low-carbon polyols on non-noble metal catalysts may involve different mechanisms. Notably, a common characteristic of the aforementioned catalysts is the excellent oxophilicity of metal sites, including noble metals such as Pt, Pd, and Au, as well as the non-noble metal Cu. In this section, we enumerate the reaction mechanisms based on different types of oxophilic catalysts, which can provide theoretical reference and guidance for researchers to design the oxophilic metal-based catalysts more rationally. 2.1 Mechanism dominated by tautomeric equilibrium between C=O and C-O groups For the mechanism dominated by tautomeric equilibrium between C=O and C-O groups pathway, 1,2 propylene glycol (1,2-PDO) oxidation to LA over Cu-based catalysts (non-noble metal catalysts) can be a typical case, as Cu is weak for the H proton abstraction, associating with its fully filled 3d orbitals and the limited availability of electron vacancies for reaction. Experimental results have shown the formation of hydroxyacetone and acetaldehyde intermediates [15]. This finding about the reaction mechanism is further probed by DFT analysis. The hydroxyacetone intermediate is formed when the secondary OH group of 1,2-PDO interacts with the acid-base site of the CuFeOX catalyst, while the C-H bond is activated at the Cu active center. For the formation of the lactaldehyde intermediate, it can be produced either through the dehydrogenation of the primary OH group in 1,2-PDO or the tautomeric equilibrium of hydroxyacetone. To gain more details about the formation mechanism of lactaldehyde, it is crucial to consider the structural characteristics of polyols. To our best knowledge, the secondary hydroxyl group is generally more reactive with the catalyst compared to the primary hydroxyl group. Moreover, in the absence of strongly electrophilic active sites, the catalyst tends to preferentially react with the secondary hydroxyl group. Therefore, the formation of lactaldehyde mainly arises from the tautomeric equilibrium of hydroxyacetone. Further DFT analysis reveals that the formation of lactaldehyde requires overcoming a higher activation Gibbs free energy (ΔG = 0.177 eV), indicating that this step constitutes the RDS of the entire reaction [11]. In summary, the detailed progress of oxidation of 1,2-PDO on the spinel CuFeOX catalyst is shown in Fig. 1 a, involving dehydrogenation of the secondary O-H group, the dehydrogenation of the C-H bond, the tautomeric equilibrium between C=O and C-O groups, along with the oxidation of lactaldehyde. Because so far, non-noble metal catalysts are primarily applied to the 1,2-PDO oxidation, there is limited research on catalyzing other low-carbon polyols. Hence, this mechanism serves as a valuable model for elucidating the role of oxophilic non-noble metal active sites in low-carbon polyol oxidation. 2.2 Mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation Glycerol (GLY), which contains three hydroxyl groups, can serve as a typical example for analyzing the oxidation of low-carbon polyols via the mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation [18–20]. Due to the lower transition state free energy for the oxidation of the primary hydroxyl group, GLY preferentially undergoes oxidation at the primary hydroxyl site, leading to the formation of the RCH2O* intermediate. For the RCH2O* intermediate, Yan identified the C-H bond activation of the RCH2O* as RDS because the step has the highest energy barrier on the Pt₁/HAP catalyst by comprehensive DFT analysis [11]. Further analysis explained the cause of the dehydrogenation of the C-H bond. In situ FT-IR analysis of GLY oxidation indicated that the RCH2O* intermediate is unstable because the surface-polarized Pt active center strongly attracts the H proton [5]. As a result, the positive charges of the C and H over Pt* increase while their distances lengthen, suggesting that the ease of losing an H proton. This finding was corroborated by kinetic isotope effect (KIE) measurements, as substituting GLY with deuterated GLY resulted in a higher KIE value (Kh/KD = 2.70), indicating the formation of RCHO [21]. During the oxidation of RCHO, the adsorption of the C=O bond by Pt significantly reduces the C-O bond distance, decreases the negative charge on O, and increases the positive charge on C, implying a low energy barrier for the formation of the C-O bond in RCHOOH. For the final C-H bond dehydrogenation of RCHOOH, DFT analysis showed that the activation energy barrier was only 1.05 kcal/mol, suggesting that RCOOH is readily formed [11]. The detailed progress of low carbon polyol oxidation to carboxylic acid is shown in Fig. 1b, involving sequential dehydrogenation of the primary O-H group, followed by dehydrogenation of the C-H bond, and oxidation of RCHO. It is evident that mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation is characterized by the strong ability of noble metal active centers to abstract H proton from the C-H bond. Given the similar H abstraction ability of noble metal active centers, the mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation can serve as a model for investigating the oxidation of other low-carbon polyols catalyzed by oxophilic noble metal catalysts. Although noble metal catalysts can effectively activate the dehydrogenation of the secondary C-H group in 1,2-PDO, their strong electrophilic nature causes direct oxidation of the secondary hydroxyl group, resulting in the formation of formic acid and acetic acid. Experimental evidence confirms that the final products of 1,2-PDO oxidation catalyzed by noble metal catalysts do not include hydroxyacetone, but only lactic acid, formic acid, and acetic acid [16]. By contrast, the nucleophilic environment offered by non-noble metal catalysts allows hydroxyacetone to be retained for a longer duration during the reaction, thus providing opportunities for tautomeric equilibrium to occur. Therefore, the oxidation of vicinal diols by oxophilic noble metals to generate primary carboxylic acids primarily follows a mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation, rather than a mechanism dominated by the tautomeric equilibrium between C=O and C-O groups. According to the above discussion, it can be concluded that low-carbon polyols tend to be activated on oxophilic metal active sites, which contribute to the formation of oxygen-containing species. Notably, the selectivity of primary carboxylic acids is enhanced by the strong H abstraction ability associated with the high electron-cloud density at oxophilic metal sites. Furthermore, oxygen-containing intermediates must have suitable adsorption strength on active sites with the appropriate electronic configuration for subsequent oxidation to occur. Therefore, the H abstraction ability and the adsorption/desorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates at oxophilic metal active sites need to be optimized accordingly. If in-situ oxygen-containing intermediates do not form or desorb from the sites near low-carbon polyol molecules, they can ultimately be detrimental to the selectivity of primary carboxylic acids. Interestingly, the catalytic oxidation of different low-carbon polyols over similar oxophilic metal catalysts can, in some cases, follow different kinetic mechanisms. However, enhancing catalytic oxidation efficiency hinges on modulating the reaction mechanism, specifically by optimizing H abstraction ability and the adsorption/desorption strengths of oxygen-containing intermediates. Indeed, different low-carbon polyols align with specific mechanisms and corresponding catalysts due to their unique chemical properties. Therefore, understanding these mechanisms is crucial for selecting catalysts, especially in terms of effectively integrating active sites with diverse functionalities and maximizing their participation in the reaction. Researchers can determine the reaction mechanisms of specific low-carbon polyols on various catalysts through experimental and theoretical analyses to understand the specific roles and behavior of active sites within the catalyst, thereby achieving precise design of highly efficient dehydrogenation-active sites. 3 Design of oxophilic metal-based catalysts for low-carbon polyols oxidation reactions Generally, the nature of the industrial source determines the type of low-carbon polyols, including ethylene glycol (EG), 1,2-PDO, GLY, 1,2-butanediol, 1,6-hexanediol, and so on. Traditional oxophilic metal-based catalysts for the low-carbon polyols oxidation often encounter several problems, such as deep oxidation of primary carboxylic acids, low conversion rates of low-carbon polyols, and uncontrollable adsorption/desorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates [22,23]. As already discussed in the previous sections, the efficiency of low-carbon polyols’ catalytic oxidation greatly depends on the activation of C-H bond and the competitive adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates. Different supported-structured oxophilic metal catalysts are applicable for different low-carbon polyols [24]. For this reason, a detailed exploration of how strategic catalyst design achieves high dehydrogenation activity and primary carboxylic acid selectivity will be provided in the conversion of various dihydric and trihydric low-carbon alcohols into primary carboxylic acids. Correspondingly, strategic oxophilic metal catalyst design will focus on advanced metal-metal interactions and metal-support interactions to optimize catalysts performance. 3.1 Glycolic acid Direct oxidation of EG provides a more practical, effective, and economical approach for producing GA [25–27]. Oxophilic noble metal-based catalysts, particularly Pt and Au, have been widely investigated for their efficacy in the oxidation of EG to GA. Typically, modified noble metal materials demonstrate improved performance due to the enhancement of their electron-donating properties [28–30]. This heightened electron-donating capacity results in greater catalytic efficiency in C-H bond activation. For Pt-based catalysts, numerous studies have proposed that a second functionality (e.g., Fe, Co, Mn, Cu, Pd, and Ni) can enhance GA yield. Highly matched d-orbital energy can facilitate efficient electron donation and induce strong metal-metal interactions, thereby leading to superior H abstraction functions. Shi studied EG oxidation to GA with Pt-Fe alloy catalyst on CeO2 support, realizing a very high TOF value of 10,080 h-1 (entry #2, Table 1 ) [29]. Kinetic tests showed that Pt and Pt-Fe catalysts exhibit distinct O₂ orders, indicating the dissociative O2 adsorption on the catalyst surface and its participation in the EG oxidation reaction. This change is primarily attributed to the reduction of d-band electron density, which weakens the Pt-O bond, thereby promoting the participation of O₂ in the EG oxidation at the active sites. They further investigated the reduction of d-band electron density with XRD analysis and found that Pt enhances Fe reduction through close interaction in the supported bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 2 a). Specifically, it is inferred that strong hybridization occurs between Pt 5d bands and highly polarized Fe 3d bands. The large difference in lattice constants between Pt and Fe metals can improve the catalytic activity. The NaY support can also enhance the electron-donating properties of Pt, as the regulation of the aluminum content in the support is a key factor determining the strength of electronic coupling with Pt active sites. Du studied the performance of dealuminization of Pt/NaY catalysts with a TOF value of 5100 h-1 (GA selectivity: 77.6%) (entry #1, Table 1) [26]. The XRD, XPS, and FTIR images of the Pt/NaY sample are shown in Fig. 2d. Rich electrons on Pt sites during oxidation reactions were observed. Dealuminization of the support was employed to shorten the Si-OH bonds, resulting in the formation of the (Si-OH)-Pt interface, which facilitates the electronic coupling effect. The valence state of the Pt species in the Pt/NaY catalyst was also studied for selective activation pathways. It was found that metallic Pt⁰ species selectively activate C-H and O-H bonds via the σ-activation pathway in the EG molecule. Moreover, this indicates that the electronic coupling effect merely enhances the electron donation from the support to Pt0 without altering the chemical valence state of Pt. Overall, the dealuminization of the NaY support promotes the electronic coupling effect at the interface, thereby improving the catalyst's dehydrogenation activation. The aforementioned measures for the modified catalysts can all make the supports discontinuously transfer electrons to Pt without ensuring the long-term dehydrogenation activity of the Pt-based catalyst. Yan studied the selective oxidation of EG to GA using Pt-Mn2O3 catalysts (entry #3, Table 1), achieving an unprecedented catalytic activity (TOF: 3196.9 h⁻¹) and a GA yield of 86.4%. The redox properties of Mn2O3 can continuously supply electrons to Pt, thereby enhancing the overall catalyst electron-donating properties. Kinetic studies of the reaction indicated that the synergy between the redox cycle of Mn2O3 and Pt enhances the adsorption of EG, activates the C-H bonds, and lowers the activation energy required for EG oxidation [31]. They further studied the promotion effect of the interfacial active sites on the adsorption of EG and the C-H bond activation. Pre-distribution of Mn2O3 within the support facilitates the formation of Pt-Mn2O3 interfacial active sites is facilitated, characterized by continuous electron transfer from Mn2O3 to Pt, as confirmed by multiple characterization techniques (mainly XANES, EXAFS, HRTEM, and XPS). The structural alterations in the metal oxide support significantly contributed to the enhanced dehydrogenation capability. A recent study on Au-based catalysts has confirmed that the strong electron-donating properties of the support can indeed enhance the H abstraction ability from the C-H bond over the active sites. Zhou studied the oxidation of alcohols using N-ligand-modified Au catalysts, which resulted in a TOF increase (6197 h-1), approaching that of the best previously reported Au catalyst with a twinning structure. They investigated the electronic properties of the Au catalyst including work function and electron density. In-situ studies and DFT calculations demonstrate that the electron-rich Au exhibits an excellent activity in gas-phase oxidation of alcohols, due to its lower work functions as well as high degree of disorder (Fig. 2b and c) [25]. The electronic effect facilitates electrophilic attack of H protons on the Au active center, thereby enhancing the dehydrogenation activity. 3.2 Lactic acid Catalytic conversion of 1,2-PDO to LA is regarded as a promising alternative to biocatalytic pathways [14]. Oxophilic metal-based catalysts, such as Cu and Pd, are commonly utilized for the oxidation of 1,2-PDO to LA. Compared to precious metals, Cu exhibits comparable catalytic activity (TOF: 1410 h-1) and achieves 94.5% selectivity toward LA [15]. The molecular structure of 1,2-PDO suggests that the catalytic behavior on Cu and Pd is similar: the terminal methyl group increases the electron density at the secondary carbon atom through inductive effects, influencing the electronic environment of the secondary hydroxyl group. This, in turn, facilitates the relatively easier activation of the C-H bond at the secondary carbon atom. For most noble metals, the interaction between active sites and the C-H bond is strong, which explains why the mechanism dominated by C-H bond dehydrogenation readily occurs on Pt and Pd surfaces [13]. For this reason, we focus only on non-noble candidates like Cu to further promote C-H bond activation by enhancing interactions with the oxygen component of the secondary hydroxyl group. For Cu-based catalysts, Cu+ has a strong electron-donating ability and can effectively form coordination bonds with the oxygen atom in the secondary hydroxyl group, which inspires assistance in the redox cycle of Cu+, thereby maintaining the stability and activity of the catalyst. Feng investigated the performances of Spinel CuFeOX magnetic catalysts, finding that CuFeOX catalysts show excellent performance obtaining 94.5% LA selectivity at 72.6% of 1,2-PDO conversion (Fig. 3 ) [14]. With an increasing Cu/Fe ratio in the magnetic nanoparticles, the conversion of 1,2-PDO and selectivity to LA were both enhanced. This is because the Cu/Fe ratio influences the Cu⁺/Cu²⁺ ratio on the catalyst surface. It is essential to further investigate how the Cu+/Cu2+ ratio influences the catalytic performance. Compared with CuFe2O4(Cu+), Cu0.5Fe1OX (Cu+ and Cu2+) MNs displayed enhanced 1,2-PDO conversion and LA selectivity (58.1% and 92.1% vs. 43.6% and 88.6%), implying that the combination of Cu+ and Cu2+ sites synergistically promote the reaction. Surprisingly, it is found that the Cu+/Cu2+ ratio also influenced the number of acid-base sites. The acid-base sites of the catalyst can promote the LA selectivity by accelerating the cleavage of the O-H bond. Therefore, by tuning the Cu/Fe ratio, surface Cu+/Cu2+ ratio and acid-base sites can facilely enhance the catalytic performance of Cu. In addition to augmenting the electron-donating ability of Cu⁺ itself, the incorporation of nitrogen, which forms stable coordination structures with copper atoms due to its lone pair electrons, can also demonstrate heightened affinity towards oxygen atoms. More recently, Feng studied 1,2-PDO oxidation with copper and nitrogen codoped porous carbon nanosheets encapsulating ultrafine Cu nanoparticles (Cu@Cu-N-C) catalysts with very high selectivity of LA (94.2%) (Fig. 4 ) [13]. They investigated the different sites of Cu@Cu-N-C catalysts including particle CuN2 and Cu0 sites. The Cu/N-C catalyst, only consisting of Cu0 sites on the support, showed 48.3% 1,2-PDO conversion and 31.7% LA yield with 65.8% LA selectivity. On the other hand, the single-atom Cu-N-C5 with only CuN2 sites exhibited a significantly enhanced LA selectivity of 87.8%, but had a low 1,2-PDO conversion of 23.4%. In contrast, Cu@Cu-N-C5 with dual Cu0 and CuN2 sites showed a remarkable increase in PDO conversion by 75.1% and LA selectivity by 88.4%, leading to a LA yield of 66.4%, which is higher than Cu/N-C catalyst and Cu-N-C5 catalyst. The observations demonstrated that the presence of dual CuN2 and Cu0 sites balances the dehydrogenation activity and oxygen reduction efficacy in the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1,2-PDO. Multicharacterizations together with kinetic studies and DFT calculations showed that the CuN2 sites were beneficial for promoting the activation of C-H bonds and suppressing C-C bond cleavage, with each site consisting of a single Cu atom coordinated with two N atoms. This coordination environment modulates the electronic properties of Cu, providing optimal electron affinity and enhancing electron transfer from the O atom in the secondary hydroxyl group. Drawing inspiration from the enhanced interactions with the oxygen component of the secondary hydroxyl group, the alloy of two strong oxophilic metals can form interactions with oxygen atoms that are twice as strong as those of a single oxophilic metal, thereby refining the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates. Feng developed Pd-Ag/HAP catalysts and investigated the influence of Ag species on the kinetics of catalytic oxidation reactions [33]. The activation energies for the catalytic oxidation of 1,2-PDO were in the order of Ea (Pd-Ag/HAP) < Ea (Pd/HAP) < Ea (Ag/HAP). For the Pd-Ag/HAP bimetallic catalysts, XRD analysis revealed alterations in the chemical states of Pd and Ag, including a reduction in the Ag 3d binding energy and a tendency for Pd 3d to alloy. Thus, introducing oxophilic metals (e.g., Ag) into Pd to modify the electronic structure helps reduce the strong binding of lactaldehyde and hydroxyacetone adsorbates and promotes stronger binding with oxygen atoms due to electron transfer from Pd to Ag, thereby improving the overall adsorption energy. Furthermore, the introduction of other metals containing d orbital electrons, such as Fe and La, can also enhance the activation of C-H or O-H bonds through electronic reconfiguration. For example, ligand interactions between La3+ atoms and the oxygen atoms of the -OH group in 1,2-PDO lead to the formation of La-diol complexes, which improve the activation of O-H bonds [34,35]. Overall, the incorporation of d-band and oxophilic metals can improve 1,2-PDO adsorption energy. 3.3 Glyceric acid Catalytic conversion of GLY to GLYA is considered a widely adopted valorization strategy [3]. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt, Au, and Pd, are most frequently employed for the oxidation of GLY to GLYA. Generally, noble metals supported on acidic supports (such as CeO2 or TiO2) demonstrate enhanced catalytic efficiency [7,36,37]. In these systems, the dehydrogenation of C-H bonds and the adsorption strength of C=O groups play crucial roles in determining the catalytic activity and selectivity during GLY oxidation. The electronic properties of metals represent a critical factor influencing bond strength, with the strength of metal-oxygen or metal-carbon bonds being directly correlated with the adsorption strength of C=O groups. Yan explored the catalytic behavior of eight metal catalysts (including Au, Pt, Ir, Ag, Pd, Rh, Ru, and Cu) for GLY oxidation to GLYA using the DFT calculation together with microkinetic analysis. The Gibbs free energy diagrams for GLY oxidation to GLYA were used to compare the catalytic behavior of eight metal catalysts. They found that the formation energy of adsorbed C and O determined the binding strength of reaction intermediates, indicating that the strength of the intermediate glyceraldehyde was controlled by the formation energy of C/O atoms on the catalyst surface (Fig. 5 a). Thus, the formation energy of adsorbed C and O can describe the kinetics of GLY oxidation to GLYA over various metals. By employing the scaling relationship between linear chemisorption energy and transition state energy, the microkinetic study demonstrated that the catalytic activity of these metals followed this order: Pt > Pd > Ir > Rh > Au > Cu > Ag > Ru (Fig. 5b). The selectivity for GLYA products across different metals was successfully predicted: Au > Pt > Ag > Pd > Rh > Ir > Cu > Ru [21]. Manipulating the formation energy of C/O atoms on the catalyst surface can mitigate the C=O adsorption strength and reasonably promote catalytic selectivity. In acidic supports, oxygen vacancies (VO) function as acidic sites that engage in interactions with metal centers, thereby actively lowering the activation energy of C-H bonds and enhancing the reactivity of the dehydrogenation reaction. Wang studied Pt/CeO2 and Au/CeO2 catalysts and systematically analyzed the effect of the VO as well as the effect of the interfacial active sites on the reaction. Bader charge analysis of Au/CeO2-X and Pt/CeO2-X interface sites revealed that the atoms around the Vo gained electrons and acquired negative charge, indicating that the Vo activated the surrounding Ce, O and Au/Pt atoms. As a result, Vo lowered the energy barrier associated with the co-dissociation reaction of O2 and H2O. DFT analysis demonstrated that the barrier of GLY C-H bond cleavage at the interface of Au/CeO2-X (1.37eV) and Pt/CeO2-X (1.29eV) was significantly reduced. Due to the synergistic effect between the metal and the support, with electrons transferring from the support to the metal, the interface became more favorable for the adsorption of activated GLY and O2. This suggests that the controlled design of interfacial active sites, along with the precise distribution of VO, is critical for key steps involving O2 dissociation and C-H dehydrogenation [2]. Currently, metal oxide supports such as CuO, TiO2, and ZrO2, along with carbon supports and molecular sieves, are being further investigated for their efficacy in supporting active centers [38–40]. Acidic sites offer the additional advantage of accepting electrons from C-H bonds, which enhances the reactivity and stability of the substrates, thereby facilitating the activation of C-H bonds. Recently, Huang developed silicon-carbon composites (Si-C-n) as novel supports for nano Pt catalysts, achieving enhanced GLY conversion (74.4%) and exceptional GLYA selectivity (86.7%). Multi-characterizations and theoretical calculations revealed that the introduced Si species generate acidic sites, which facilitated the rapid desorption of the GLYA product from Pt/Si-C-n, thereby promoting electronic contact between Pt and the support (Fig. 5c). This contact led to high activity and selectivity for GLYA production [2]. Therefore, introducing acidic sites and enhancing the strength of electronic interactions between Pt and the support significantly influence the catalytic performance in GLY oxidation (Table 2 ). 3.4 2-Hydroxybutyric acid Catalytic conversion of 1,2-butanediol to 2-hydroxybutyric acid is considered a key route in sustainable chemical processes [44,45]. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt, Au, and Pd are most frequently utilized for 1,2-butanediol oxidation to 2-hydroxybutyric acid. Generally, noble metals supported on amphoteric supports (such as ZnO or HAP) provide an effective strategy for further boosting catalytic performance [32,45]. This is because the acid-base characteristics of the catalyst supports affect the distribution of products. A well-established consensus indicates that an increase in the quantity of acidic sites within amphoteric supports promotes the activation of C-H bonds, while an optimal distribution of basic sites contributes to the stabilization of reaction intermediates. Li studied the reaction mechanism for 1,2-butanediol oxidation to 2-hydroxybutyric acid using HAP-supported Pd catalysts that exhibited excellent selectivity for 2-hydroxybutyric acid. Systematic activity evaluations and catalyst characterizations demonstrated that the surface Pd(II) species were highly relevant to catalytic oxidation activity. The enhanced catalytic activity was specifically proved by the strong β-H dehydrogenation ability of the Pd(II) species, due to its partially filled d orbital and significant acidity. Notably, the acidic sites on the surface not only promote the electronic reconfiguration of the Pd(II) species, thereby enhancing the activation of C-H bonds, but also facilitate electron density transfer to the oxygen atoms, improving the adsorption and activation of hydroxyl oxygen. In addition, coordination between the primary hydroxyl group and the basic Ca²⁺ sites in the HAP support further promoted the primary hydroxyl group oxidation, meanwhile allowing the secondary hydroxyl group to remain untouched (Fig. 6 a) [32]. Therefore, designing composite supports with tunable acid-base properties can further enhance the activity of noble metal catalysts. As an acidic site within HAP, PO₄³⁻ can amplify its acidic characteristics not only through an increase in its quantity but also by ameliorating its coordination environment, thereby further elevating its intrinsic acidity. Yan investigated the performance of the Pt1/HAP catalyst for the selective oxidation of C2-C4 polyols (Fig. 6b) [5]. They confirmed that the presence of a strongly electron-withdrawing group such as PO4 3- improves both conversion and selectivity for 2-hydroxybutyric acid. The presence of PO4 3- could coordinate with Pt, leading to the formation of Pt1–OPO4 3- pair active sites, contributing to achieving the activation of the C-H bond and destabilizing the transition state from adsorbed hydroxy acids toward the C-C cleavage. This is the main reason for remarkable catalytic selectivity and catalyst stability. Notably, the formation of Pt1–OPO4 3- active sites could further enhance the acidity of the support, thereby improving the activation efficiency of the C-H bond [5]. Overall, the strong PO4 3- coordination effect of Pt1/HAP can significantly enhance the Lewis acidity of the metal center, thereby improving the activation efficiency of the C-H bond. One prevalent strategy for escalating the catalytic performance of metal-amphoteric support systems involves leveraging the polarization effect of active sites to augment the synergy between the metal-OH* sites and the amphoteric support. The metal-OH* sites possess a vigorous electronegativity, enabling them to effectively attract electrons and ease electron transfer. This electron transfer mechanism interacts with the basic sites provided by VO, thereby fostering the efficient activation of both the C-H and O-H bonds in the reactants. Yan studied the role of the Au-ZnO interface (characterization in Fig. 7 c) in the selective oxidation of 1,2-butanediol, achieving high conversion (>60%) and selectivity (>80%). They found that the abundant oxygen vacancies (VO) lead to Zn atoms exhibiting stronger Lewis acidity, which contributes to the enhanced adsorption of the secondary hydroxyl group (Fig. 7a). Meanwhile, the basic VO sites also promote electron absorption properties on the ZnO (001) surface, which plays a critical role in O-H bond activation (0.61 eV). Additionally, the Auδ+-OH* sites, with their strong electrostatic forces, allow for polarization of chemical bonds at these interfaces. This facilitates the extraction of hydrogen from the C-H bond of the key intermediate by attracting electrons from the C-H bond, thereby lowering its bond dissociation barrier (Fig. 7b) [42]. The Auδ+-OH* sites and the amphoteric support ZnO can synergistically enhance the specific product selectivity. 3.5 6-Hydroxyhexanoic acid Catalytic conversion of 1,6-hexanediol is regarded as a sustainable HA manufacturing process [46,47]. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt and Au, are the most prevalent for 1,6-hexanediol oxidation to AA. Generally, non-noble metals such as Bi and Sn are often used as secondary promoters to reduce the competitive adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates, driven by the electronic reconfiguration of metallic centers [48–50]. On the other hand, noble metals like Pt and Pd are frequently selected as secondary metals to enhance C-H bond dehydrogenation activity because of their strong electronic acceptor properties [22,51]. These approaches effectively optimize catalytic performance and mitigate catalyst deactivation. The partially filled d orbitals of Pd and Pt facilitate the establishment of robust electronic interactions with Au, characterized by a higher electron density, thus pushing the electronic reconfiguration. Mounguengui-Diallo studied Au-Pd and Au-Pt bimetallic catalysts with a high initial selectivity for HA [50]. This higher yield compared with the Au catalyst is primarily attributed to the rearrangement of the electronic structure in the Au active center. It seems to create a suitable reaction environment, which can significantly enhance the TOF of the oxidation reaction. Such an electronic surrounding is often believed to act as the H proton capture pool for activation of C-H bonds in 1,6-hexanediol molecules. Furthermore, the application of capping agents, such as polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), can also improve the selectivity of HA by modulating the metal's electron density and facilitating the electron transfer. In contrast to other low-carbon polyols, the relatively larger molecular weight of 1,6-hexanediol introduces steric hindrance, which restricts its effective engagement with the catalyst's active sites, thereby resulting in a deterioration of catalytic activity. Xie conducted a kinetic study of the deactivation of carbon-supported Pt nanoparticles in 1,6-hexanediol oxidation. They found that the initial turnover frequency of 0.54 s-1 (at 343 K and 1 MPa O2) decreases significantly with reaction time because of product competitive adsorption and irreversible adsorption of unknown strongly bonded species. To mitigate this harmful adsorption, the introduction of promoters, such as Sn or Bi, has been proven effective, owing to the enhanced scavenging rate of detrimental intermediates on the Pt surface and the reduced adsorption of detrimental intermediates through the formation of Bi complexes [48,49]. It is inferred that the electron-withdrawing effect of Bi or Sn makes the activation of the C-H bonds in the target intermediates more selectively sensitive to Au, leading to the desorption of by-products and thus enhancing the selectivity for HA. 4 Conclusions and outlooks In this paper, we have summarized the most recent advances in the conversion of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids. Recent research has focused on the design principles of oxophilic metal catalysts for the conversion of low-carbon polyols and their underlying reaction mechanisms. The influence of surface chemistry on oxophilic metal catalysts is also discussed. Au-, Pd-, Pt-, and Cu-based oxophilic catalysts exhibit relatively superior performance. It is important to be aware that the shift in the d-band center of oxophilic metal sites and the distribution of acid-base sites on the support are critical factors governing the efficiency of C-H activation reactions. The effects of hydrogen abstraction abilities vary significantly among oxophilic metal catalysts. In general, a downshifted d-band center of oxophilic metal sites, well-dispersed acidic sites, and a considerable amount of weak basic sites explicitly help in H abstraction efficiency. In the future, our primary focus should be on the development of reaction mechanisms based on the design of catalytic active sites, as well as finding ways to reduce the cost of catalysts. The following aspects should be addressed in future research efforts. (i) Development of acid/base-controllable molecular sieve catalysts for facile C=O adsorption of aldehyde intermediates in a base-free medium. Rational design of molecular sieve materials is key to the efficient synthesis of primary carboxylic acids from low-carbon polyols. The specific pore structure of molecular sieve materials plays a crucial role in the implementation of low-carbon polyol oxidation technologies. (ii) Effective nonnoble catalysts need to be developed for the dehydrogenation of C-H, as this process is an essential step in producing carboxylic acids. Efficient nonnoble catalysts replacing noble catalysts show great promise for the future development of dehydrogenation technologies. (iii) Reaction mechanism of oxidation of low-carbon polyol is highly desired in upcoming research efforts. Although the above two mechanisms are reasonable for oxidation of low-carbon polyol, changes in the catalyst active site environment lead to dynamic changes in the reaction mechanism. Selective oxidation of low-carbon polyols is one of the key technologies in catalytic upgrading of carboxylic acid products. Therefore, ongoing efforts to improve the atomic and energetic efficiency of the active center are key to the establishment of catalyst design. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids is regarded as an important technology for sustainable traditional oxidation processes in industry. Despite decades of research and several breakthroughs in catalyst design, the precise reaction mechanism underlying the formation of specific carboxylic acids remains elusive. In this review, the oxidation of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids over metallic catalysts is systematically summarized with a focus on surface reaction mechanisms and catalyst design strategies. Essentially, the activation of C-H bond and the competitive adsorption/desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates serve as critical issues in determining the reaction mechanism. Insights into the reaction mechanism, the structure-performance relationships of oxophilic metal-based catalysts in various low-carbon polyol oxidation reactions lay the groundwork for rational catalyst design and manufacturing: (I) well-dispersed acidic sites can enhance the electronic density of oxophilic metals, thereby improving the H abstraction efficiency, while an adequate number of weak basic sites on the surface is beneficial for the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates; (II) the downshifted d-band center of oxophilic metal sites results in greater catalytic efficiency for C-H bond activation. This review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of oxidation mechanisms and guide the rational design of efficient catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic oxidation of low-carbon polyols to primary carboxylic acids: Advances on catalyst design and mechanistic studies
